data.text: President Christine @Lagarde introduces the baseline GDP and inflation outlook for the euro area. https://t.co/WaH5GmGNR3
Watch the ECB press conference live: President Christine @Lagarde explains today’s monetary policy decisions. https://t.co/qGJwpFn0RH
Coming up in 15 minutes: watch live as President Christine @Lagarde explains the latest monetary policy decisions. https://t.co/ttKfmOyiuw
Press release: Monetary policy decisions https://t.co/wyDGA4COxO
Later today: watch live as ECB President Christine @Lagarde explains the latest monetary policy decisions. https://t.co/tWkbn9KLfr
Euro area bank interest rate statistics (April 2021) https://t.co/FoScMv0wdG

Central banks and supervisors have shown their resolve within their mandates to integrate the effects of the climate crisis in the exercise of their tasks, says Executive Board member @FrankElderson in a speech. He also speaks about the work of the @NGFS_  https://t.co/bHAFUwNx8V https://t.co/PzyzH0o6hw https://t.co/VVgFVHMvDk

Are you conducting research on inflation? Submit your paper and present your research at our online conference organised with the Centre for Inflation Research @ClevelandFed. Our call for papers is open until 1 July 2021 https://t.co/vuApGjnrRx https://t.co/Y8jIZiluor

Watch live from 15:45 CET today: Executive Board member @FrankElderson speaks about the work of the @NGFS_ and the role of central banks and supervisors in dealing with the climate crisis at the #GreenSwanConference by @BIS_org, @banquedefrance and @NGFS_  https://t.co/z7YR1eoN1g https://t.co/L3809jL1X0

Issuing a well-designed digital euro could not only preserve the role of the euro in domestic payments, but also enhance its global role, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta on the international role of the euro. Read the report here https://t.co/x41wUH458i https://t.co/7nus8cHpuH

With the right mix of fiscal, economic and monetary policies we can build a better monetary union which could increase the influence of the euro, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta on the international role of the euro. Read the report https://t.co/x41wUH458i https://t.co/fEi5iU8C8H

Persistent low growth and low inflation after the euro crisis also proved the importance of a balanced policy mix. Strong policy support now will continue to provide a bridge across the pandemic and well into the economic recovery. Read the speech https://t.co/jNpohvKryM 4/4

The eurozone sovereign debt crisis taught us that in such periods, the most important signal for policymakers is their determination to act. At the onset of the pandemic, we reacted quickly and forcefully, showing there are no limits to our commitment to the euro 3/4

The global financial crisis showed why we needed effective financial regulation. Europe learnt the lesson and strengthened its banking system, meaning that when the pandemic hit, banks could be mobilised to channel funding to the economy 2/4

(THREAD) Learning from past crises has helped us to avert what would have been the greatest crisis of them all during the pandemic, President @Lagarde explains upon receiving the Turgot Prize of Honour. Three lessons in particular have shaped Europe’s progress 1/4 https://t.co/d03iXNVaSO
Do you read our Supervision Newsletter? Help us make it work better for you. Share your thoughts with us in our survey https://t.co/UKk7cXVkY3 https://t.co/ZVRAagm2FS

Explore the report’s special features on 
- the impact of a central bank digital currency on the international role of currencies
- the implications of the EU and ECB policy responses to the pandemic 
- the euro as an invoicing currency for global trade
https://t.co/x41wUH458i

The euro remained a key currency in international green bond markets, with over half of green bonds issued globally in 2020 in euro. Developing well-functioning euro markets for sustainable and green finance can strengthen the euro’s international role

(THREAD) The international role of the euro is broadly stable after the pandemic shock and the euro remains the second most used currency in the world after the US dollar. Read the press release https://t.co/N8o0HT6p0d https://t.co/96ovJj4WTL

Watch live from 12:15 CET today: Executive Board member @FrankElderson participates in a panel on how the financial sector can take action against climate-related risks at the #GreenSwanConference by @BIS_org, @Banquedefrance and @NGFS_ https://t.co/79N08QBRpb https://t.co/HyWWDD2jSD
Working Paper: The risk management approach to macro-prudential policy https://t.co/t8OLovxymh
Euro area insurance corporation statistics (Q1 2021) https://t.co/L1gJ5usmik

Services such as tourism, entertainment and travel were hit most in the first half of 2020. But they have also rebounded less in the second half, further increasing the divergence across sectors. 

Read more on this story and others in the full report https://t.co/vFZgFHUd7i 2/2 https://t.co/52ysKlVzQq

(THREAD) The charts in our latest Financial Stability Review tell many stories. One is that of the uneven impact of the pandemic.

Less badly affected sectors, such as manufacturing, have been able to resume normal activity, while the services sector has suffered 1/2 https://t.co/MDvpeDQ7c6
Working Paper: Combining negative rates, forward guidance and asset purchases: identification and impacts of the ECB’s unconventional policies https://t.co/YPr26ozckw
Working Paper: The Covid pandemic in the market: infected, immune and cured bonds https://t.co/VRj1Iowqj2

The availability of bank loans improved marginally, but not for the smallest firms. Looking ahead, SMEs continue to be concerned about the availability of external financing. Read the results https://t.co/FFiwTtaUGA 3/3
Small and medium-sized enterprises’ turnover and profits continued to deteriorate, but business activity is expected to improve in the coming months 2/3

(THREAD) Our latest survey results on the access to finance of enterprises reflect the difficult economic environment caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Most small businesses highlighted the importance of government support to meet their obligations 1/3 https://t.co/AjS7tLyqML
Working paper: Point targets, tolerance bands, or target ranges? Inflation target types and the anchoring of inflation expectations https://t.co/Zk3RlXClU9
Working paper: Euro area sovereign bond risk premia during the Covid-19 pandemic https://t.co/ywWFlHPvyr
How did euro area bank lending and money supply evolve in April? How do they compare with March’s figures? Find out more in the press release https://t.co/wQrR757TtV https://t.co/eS0ly7dsBJ
Research bulletin: How has the COVID-19 crisis affected different households’ consumption in the euro area? https://t.co/c9UhfXqITB

Banks facilitated government support to counter the impact of the pandemic. We looked at how banks implemented the financial relief measures to check whether they had done so in an adequate manner. https://t.co/FBpKgIdsu3

Some sectors are more sensitive to the pandemic shock than others. We looked at banks’ exposure to the food and accommodation sector and found that not all are operating in line with supervisory expectations. https://t.co/2UB8wMnExp

The pandemic may have a delayed impact on banks’ loan books. We assessed whether banks are prepared to deal with an increase in distressed debtors and found gaps in their credit risk management. Read about this and more in the Supervision Newsletter 
https://t.co/KO8iK4LFJ6 https://t.co/BJEHV921Gl

Our targeted review of internal models (TRIM) looked at how 65 banks model risk. What’s behind this large-scale project, what were our findings and what lies ahead? Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/KO8iK4LFJ6 https://t.co/nbn0pgkLYT
Working Paper: What drives euro area financial market developments? The role of US spillovers and global risk https://t.co/3Zy0ozDhfI
Working Paper: On the effectiveness of macroprudential policy https://t.co/j2ui2rN9JR

Diverse and experienced non-executive board members in banks play a key role, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. They can oversee and constructively challenge executive directors, thereby promoting better decision-making https://t.co/FvCT5Hu6Wj https://t.co/IWFynIx7vt

Register now and watch live from 13:00 CET: Andrea Enria speaks about banks’ internal governance at @EUI_FBF_School 
https://t.co/wQ9jQBfbhy https://t.co/jilGlYi6Zw

The outlook has brightened but the recovery depends on continued policy support, Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel tells @Reuters. PEPP asset purchases depend on financing conditions and the inflation outlook. There will be no mechanical tapering https://t.co/UcdNGV8SJB https://t.co/EWxpxRVL1F

In search of higher yields, banks have pursued creative strategies which increase valuation risk. What do our findings show about banks’ practices and what can be done to improve them? Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/KO8iK53gAE https://t.co/gXIcBBPjO0

Support for the euro has hit a record high! 80% of people living in the euro area think that having the euro is a good thing for the EU, the latest Eurobarometer survey shows. See full results here https://t.co/4ZWYXq9wzM https://t.co/hNMktH4VX3

Many citizens call for a more active role by central banks in tackling societal challenges such as climate change, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. As an independent central bank, we have a duty to respond to these concerns within our mandate. https://t.co/hXAqQCWquQ https://t.co/6NJJaSLDHe

Register now and watch live from 15:30 CET: Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel speaks about societal responsibility and central bank independence at the VIII. New Paradigm Workshop organised by @ForumNewEconomy https://t.co/aCr00AgQ01

Strengthening financial integration within the EU is vital to protect our economy from shocks and financial instability, says Vice-President Luis de Guindos. The risks posed by climate change add further urgency to the need to act https://t.co/DmEOKlgGnA https://t.co/pTy9hjg4cn

Watch live from 11:45 CET: the European Financial Integration and Stability conference continues with remarks from Vice-President Luis de Guindos and a panel on the impact of climate change, moderated by Executive Board member @FrankElderson https://t.co/F0g9A7vHro
#EFSIR https://t.co/e5DJuvs7BP

Embracing technology makes banking supervision more effective, says Supervisory Board member Pentti Hakkarainen. It helps us to more efficiently and quickly understand banking sector risks  https://t.co/Gc7mgMFGGL https://t.co/frq4bCNWrC
Working Paper: The COVID-19 shock and challenges for time series models https://t.co/RETLNl6Yc3
EU structural financial indicators (end of 2020) https://t.co/hsIDa60nZi

With benchmark rate reforms just around the corner, banks need to act now to reduce transition risks. They should decrease legacy exposures to rates that will be discontinued. Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/KO8iK4LFJ6 https://t.co/DRgwHXBUha

Panetta on a digital euro: A digital euro would protect privacy, increase consumer choice, reduce transaction costs and support the digitalisation of the economy. It would also provide safe, sovereign money as a public good 3/3

Panetta on the pandemic emergency purchase programme: The conditions that we see today do not justify reducing the pace of purchases, and a discussion about phasing out the PEPP is still premature. We need to continue to act forcefully to reach our inflation aim 2/3

(THREAD) The economic situation is improving, but the recovery is not yet self-sustaining, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta. A premature withdrawal of policy support would risk suffocating the recovery. Full interview https://t.co/6wPeOHmCxt 1/3 https://t.co/6PlM0b3cZn

Watch live from 16:00 CET: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane joins a panel discussing our ongoing strategy review.

Employment, climate change and the interaction between monetary and fiscal policies are all on the agenda for discussion.

https://t.co/eEwEtTl911 https://t.co/y45YrqZ9Bi

Register via the link ⬇️ for this year’s online conference on European Financial Integration and Stability on 27 May with our Vice-President Luis de Guindos. Discussions will focus on how the pandemic and climate change affect our financial system.
#EFSIR @EU_Commission https://t.co/5vQjBaRPbS

Last call to enter the young economists’ competition by 30 May for the opportunity to attend the #ECBForum and win €10,000! Check our website for more details https://t.co/T5gP5b6LHR https://t.co/F9bYCGpare

Large investment firms in Europe will be subject to a new regulatory regime from June that will better reflect the risks they take and make supervision more efficient. Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/KO8iK4LFJ6 https://t.co/NTS319kbhE

Credit risk has not peaked yet so we can’t lower our guard, says Supervisory Board Vice-Chair @FrankElderson. He also talks about climate risks and diversity on banks’ boards. Read about this and more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/Ke53RJ4ILS https://t.co/uIT0Xv8LDH
Working Paper: The effect of macroeconomic uncertainty on household spending https://t.co/SKZBCDZh2E

ECB Banking Supervision is establishing a Market Contact Group to discuss relevant banking issues with senior market professionals. We welcome expressions of interest from investors, analysts and market participants https://t.co/drtOZTM3J5 https://t.co/6qBope9fUd

At the ECB we constantly monitor and steer inflation to guarantee price stability. Our new interactive tool helps you explore euro area inflation and calculate your personal inflation rate in 23 EU languages https://t.co/fAj9dfZOFf https://t.co/113mAh8mVB

The Supervision Newsletter is almost five years old, and now we want to hear your views! Share your thoughts on the newsletter by completing our survey https://t.co/UKk7cXVkY3

What does Supervisory Board Vice-Chair Frank Elderson have to say about credit risk during the pandemic? Who supervises investment firms? And how can banks prepare for benchmark rate reforms? Read about this and more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/KO8iK4LFJ6 https://t.co/DCHG2uct4H

How has financial stability fared during Europe’s third coronavirus wave? What has been the impact on banks, firms and people, and which challenges are shaping the road to recovery?
Find out in our May 2021 Financial Stability Review https://t.co/59BJ3Fc7jV https://t.co/FcPeexIgke

To increase choice and resilience, the European payments ecosystem must stimulate competition by establishing innovative payment solutions and technologies developed in Europe. Read more about our strategy https://t.co/kAs1wmapSp

We want to promote digital and instant retail payment solutions that are developed in Europe and can be used by everyone, everywhere, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta at @SuomenPankki. This underpins our work on a possible digital euro. Speech https://t.co/qQmI8kD9d7 https://t.co/vb5bV2OIGI

We are looking for a new Head of Global Media Relations, who will lead work on the ECB’s media strategy, provide strategic communication advice and maintain relationships with media around the world.

Read the vacancy notice https://t.co/ojaKWcuPEP https://t.co/89OgTQZnxa
Preparatory note for the Eurogroup meeting on 21 May 2021 https://t.co/2wZpm0ymlA
Working Paper: Lending relationships in loan renegotiation - Evidence from corporate loans https://t.co/M0ZBlHIczj
Euro money market statistics (2nd maintenance period 2021) https://t.co/NGJaSCG29s

Policy support during the pandemic has prevented a wave of insolvencies but is it keeping unprofitable firms alive? How might these zombie companies affect economic recovery? Find out in a preview of our Financial Stability Review https://t.co/kgivhNzgE1 https://t.co/taJZfteaJI
Working Paper: Funding behaviour of debt management offices and the ECB’s Public Sector Purchase Programme https://t.co/h0qkJcX07t

Enhanced climate-related disclosures and more effective green financing are essential for a smooth transition towards a sustainable economy and for reducing vulnerability to climate-related risks. Read more https://t.co/rpWpw2iCQP 5/5

Financial risks could also emerge from the link between banks and insurers as extreme weather events become more frequent. In the eurozone, only one-third of climate-related economic losses are insured, and climate change is expected to widen this protection gap 4/5

Climate change hazards could have an impact on up to one-third of eurozone banks’ credit exposures, as some firms are already highly exposed or are becoming increasingly exposed to physical risks – usually concentrated in certain regions 3/5 https://t.co/h0GkrEMRGG

Banks are exposed to sectors with high emissions, to varying degrees. The manufacturing sector presents a major source of climate-related credit risk if you consider indirect emissions and the impact of possible consumer preference changes on demand 2/5 https://t.co/uGPw7JWB7P

(THREAD) We urgently need a better understanding of climate-related risks. In an analysis published in our upcoming Financial Stability Review, we find that exposure to climate risks is concentrated among certain sectors, regions and banks https://t.co/rpWpw2iCQP 1/5 https://t.co/6tND2ZN81b

Within our mandate, there is an obligation to take climate change into account, says Executive Board member @FrankElderson. Tune into the #TheECBPodcast with our new host @KatieRanger_ about how we at the ECB can contribute to tackling climate change https://t.co/GcwD4Rfr3Y https://t.co/UtE4pZEPg3
Decisions taken by the Governing Council of the ECB (in addition to decisions setting interest rates) https://t.co/UEVqhuwzH7
Working Paper: The disciplining effect of supervisory scrutiny in the EU-wide stress test https://t.co/Wn4FBZCJCh
Working Paper: Do banks fuel climate change? https://t.co/Mtp2295A2V

Payment services in Europe are constantly evolving and we want to evolve alongside the latest trends and technologies. Our new retail payments strategy supports the creation of a pan-European payment solution and aims to improve instant payments. Our goals https://t.co/kAs1wmapSp https://t.co/oDiVCuvRWB

We are taking on new supervisory tasks in the area of securitisation. They relate to risk retention, transparency and the ban on re-securitisation. This helps in implementing the regulatory framework for a well-functioning securitisation market https://t.co/jPmOgtyPdf https://t.co/j4y24N3Fgl

Our sanctioning powers help to ensure that banks comply with regulatory requirements, say Supervisory Board member Edouard Fernandez-Bollo and Director General Pedro Gustavo Teixeira. This in turn creates confidence in the soundness of the banking system https://t.co/xXmOtM2Zlg https://t.co/tMxqKJg1RK

Young researchers wanted! If you are a PhD student in economics or finance, enter our young economists’ competition for the opportunity to share your work at the #ECBForum and win €10,000. Submit your application by 30 May https://t.co/JD2vUfYBaH https://t.co/k47Xw6ox8n

Restructuring distressed debt early is good for banks and borrowers, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. If banks “wait and see” this could lead to bankruptcies at a later stage 
https://t.co/IxLQp5Rgaf EL
